section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards (Mm, Nn), My Mess, In Nature, drawing and writing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We saw the letter m in the word make and the letter n in the word need.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Mm Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letter Mm. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase M . The letter M makes the /m/ sound you hear in the word milk. This is lowercase m. The letter m makes the /m/ sound you hear in mitten.

Teach Nn Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letter Nn. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase N. The letter N makes the /n/ sound you hear in the word nut. This is lowercase n. The letter n makes the /n/ sound you hear in nest.
Explain the Activity Share My Mess and In Nature. Today, we will read a book about the letter Mm and a book about the letter Nn.
Read Read aloud My Mess with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Touch your shoulder when you hear a word that begins with the /m/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud In Nature with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Raise your hand when you hear a word that begins with the /n/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Mm and Nn. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read My Mess, stop at each word that begins with the letter Mm. Have children say /m/ and the word that begins with Mm. Repeat with In Nature and the letter Nn. For children who need assistance, before writing have them trace letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Invite them to name other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.

When reviewing the letter sounds for Mm and Nn, respond by repeating the letter sound and name. For example: After a child answers that moon begins with /m/, say “Yes, moon begins with the sound /m/. The letter m stands for the sound /m/.” Hold up the Mm Alphabet Card. Point out that the lowercase m has two humps and the n has only one hump.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Clear cup, water, shaving cream, food coloring

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Weather. We were curious and asked questions to find out more about weather. What is one thing about weather that you’re curious about?
Just like we asked questions about what we learned in the book Weather, we can use our curiosity everywhere!
Today we’re going to use our curiosity and ask questions as we investigate why rain falls. We’re going to set up a science experiment. Let’s observe and be curious together!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Have a clear cup already filled with water. Tell children that the water represents the air.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s be curious together! What do you think will happen if I add the shaving cream to the water?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Add a thin layer of shaving cream to the water.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s be curious! Why do you think I used shaving cream? What does shaving cream remind you of?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Put a few drops of food coloring on the cloud.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What do you think will happen now? Let’s see what happens!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Curiosity Once the experiment is complete, ask children what questions they have about the experiment. How does being curious about the weather help us learn more about the weather?

Provide extra support during the experiment by analyzing each material used. Have a simple picture of the water cycle available. Explain how the water represents air, the shaving cream represents a cloud, and the food coloring represents rain drops.

Challenge children to consider what will happen if the water in the cup is heated. Expand the parameters of the experiment by asking children to think about other materials that can be used instead of water, shaving cream, and food coloring to model rain.
Learning about weather is a great connector for English and multilingual learners. Why? Because weather affects all of us. Revisit terms like water, water vapor, clouds, and raindrops.

Children will be drawn to the experiment. If you need their attention, place the cup out of sight until you’re ready for children to observe. This will ensure a successful combination of keen observation and active listening and discussion.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Large sheets of blue construction paper, white paint, gray paint, feathers, cotton balls, sponge pieces

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Weather . We learned about different kinds of clouds. Can you remember what cumulus clouds look like? Stratus clouds? Cirrus clouds?
In this activity, we will use art to show the three different kinds of clouds we learned about.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Review the relationship between the different clouds and weather. Emphasize that clouds are distinguished by appearance.
Model Model the activity using the materials. Point out the color and shape differences in the type of clouds.
Pass Out Materials Each child should have a sheet of blue construction paper that’s been tri-folded horizontally.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Dip your feather in paint and make gentle lines in the top section of your paper.
Who can tell me what kind of clouds these are? (cirrus)

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Dip cotton balls in paint and dab in the center section to make cumulus clouds, and dip a sponge in gray paint and make thick lines on the bottom section to make stratus clouds. Ask children to name the clouds you made. Then, invite children to make clouds on their papers.
Talk About Clouds Invite children to talk about each type of cloud. When we see cumulus clouds, is it a sunny or rainy day? What’s your favorite kind of cloud?

By depicting all three cloud types on one sheet of paper, children can learn the typical position of each cloud in the sky. Some children may find it easier to use an entire sheet of paper for each cloud type. If so, display cirrus on top, cumulus in the middle, stratus on bottom.

Encourage children to be curious about clouds. Support them in searching online for images of these other cloud types. Challenge children to make representations of these additional clouds on other sheets of blue paper. Invite them to share their findings with the class.

Science vocabulary is most likely new to most children, so English and non-English speakers are starting from the same place. In this lesson, sit multilingual and English learners next to each other to encourage conversation using the new vocabulary—stratus, cirrus, cumulus clouds.

For children who have difficulty pronouncing the different sounds in multi-syllable words, say each cloud name syllable by syllable. Have children repeat after you. For example, say “cu” “mu” “lus”; “stra” “tus”; and “cir” “rus.” Make sure children are able to see you. Point to your mouth as you enunciate each syllable.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Drawing paper, markers, and crayons

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read What’s the Weather? We talked about the things we can do in different kinds of weather.
Today, we will make our own book about weather!

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: First, choose a type of weather.
Then, each of you will draw a picture of something you do in that kind of weather and write the name on the picture.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model I’ll choose rainy weather! Model writing Rainy at the top of the paper. When it’s rainy, I love to sit under a blanket in my favorite chair and read a book. I’ll draw myself doing that!
Ask Ask children to pick the weather they want to contribute to the book.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Who wants to make a page for windy? Snowy? Rainy? Sunny?
Find your weather word on the board. Write it at the top of your paper.
ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Point to the top of a paper.
ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read, we read from top to bottom. We do the same thing when we write.
Now draw yourself doing something in the weather you chose.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Share Invite children to share their drawings.

Make Table of Contents Let’s make a table of contents like the one in the Big Book. Should I write Table of Contents at the top or bottom of the paper? Where should I start writing—on the left or right? What should we list in our table of contents? Add entries: Rainy, Snowy, Windy, Sunny.
Bind Explain that you’ll bind the pages together into a class book.

Suggest that children flip through some of the weather books in the classroom library if they are having trouble thinking of an activity to draw. Ask questions to guide thinking, such as Why did you pick snowy weather? Do you like to play in the snow?

Invite children to contribute a page for all four weather types. If they haven’t experienced a particular type of weather, tell them to draw themselves doing what they think they would like to do in that kind of weather.

Invite multilingual learners to create two pages with the same drawing. Above one drawing they can write the weather word in English. Above the second drawing, they can write the weather word in their native language.

Children may need support writing the weather label. Provide extra support and assistance in guiding children to write the labels. If necessary, write the weather word on a piece of paper and allow children to attach the label to their page.
